parts:
Provide your commentary to Dario Amodei's latest remarks, given his stature as a leader in the field of Generative AI.

---

A statement from Dario Amodei on Anthropic's commitment to American AI leadership
Oct 21, 2025
●
6 min read

A statement from Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei on Anthropic’s commitment to advancing America's leadership in building powerful and beneficial AI.

Anthropic is built on a simple principle: AI should be a force for human progress, not peril. That means making products that are genuinely useful, speaking honestly about risks and benefits, and working with anyone serious about getting this right. I strongly agree with Vice President JD Vance's recent comments on AI—particularly his point that we need to maximize applications that help people, like breakthroughs in medicine and disease prevention, while minimizing the harmful ones. This position is both wise and what the public overwhelmingly wants.

Anthropic is the fastest-growing software company in history, with revenue growing from a $1B to $7B run rate over the last nine months, and we've managed to do this while deploying AI thoughtfully and responsibly. There are products we will not build and risks we will not take, even if they would make money.

Our longstanding position is that managing the societal impacts of AI should be a matter of policy over politics. I fully believe that Anthropic, the administration, and leaders across the political spectrum want the same thing: to ensure that powerful AI technology benefits the American people and that America advances and secures its lead in AI development.

Despite our track record of communicating frequently and transparently about our positions, there has been a recent uptick in inaccurate claims about Anthropic's policy stances. Some are significant enough that they warrant setting the record straight.

Our alignment with the Trump administration on key areas of AI policy

We work directly with the federal government in several ways. In July the Department of War awarded Anthropic a two-year, $200 million agreement to prototype frontier AI capabilities that advance national security. We have partnered with the General Services Administration to offer Claude for Enterprise and Claude for Government for $1 across the federal government. And Claude is deployed across classified networks through partners like Palantir and at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
Anthropic publicly praised President Trump’s AI Action Plan. We have been supportive of the President’s efforts to expand energy provision in the US in order to win the AI race, and I personally attended an AI and energy summit in Pennsylvania with President Trump, where he and I had a good conversation about US leadership in AI. Anthropic’s Chief Product Officer attended a White House event where we joined a pledge to accelerate healthcare applications of AI, and our Head of External Affairs attended the White House’s AI Education Taskforce event to support their efforts to advance AI fluency for teachers.
Every major AI company has hired policy experts from both parties and recent administrations—Anthropic is no different. We've hired Republicans and Democrats alike, and built an advisory council that includes senior former Trump administration officials. Anthropic makes hiring decisions based on candidates' expertise, integrity, and competence, not their political affiliations.
We (and many other organizations) respectfully disagreed with a single proposed amendment in the One Big Beautiful Bill: the 10-year moratorium on state-level AI laws, which would have blocked any action without offering a federal alternative. That specific provision was voted down by Republicans and Democrats in a 99-1 vote in the Senate. Our longstanding position has been that a uniform federal approach is preferable to a patchwork of state laws. I proposed such a standard months ago and we’re ready to work with both parties to make it happen.
Our preference for a national AI standard

While we continue to advocate for that federal standard, AI is moving so fast that we can’t wait for Congress to act. We therefore supported a carefully designed bill in California where most of America’s leading AI labs are headquartered, including Anthropic. This bill, SB 53, requires the largest AI developers to make their frontier model safety protocols public and is written to exempt any company with an annual gross revenue below $500M—therefore only applying to the very largest AI companies. Anthropic supported this exemption to protect startups and in fact proposed an early version of it.
Some have suggested that we are somehow interested in harming the startup ecosystem. Startups are among our most important customers. We work with tens of thousands of startups and partner with hundreds of accelerators and VCs. Claude is powering an entirely new generation of AI-native companies. Damaging that ecosystem makes no sense for us.
I've heard arguments that state AI regulation could slow down the US AI industry and hand China the lead. But the real risk to American AI leadership isn't a single state law that only applies to the largest companies—it's filling the PRC's data centers with US chips they can't make themselves. We agree with leaders like Senators Tom Cotton and Josh Hawley that this would only help the Chinese Communist Party win the race to the AI frontier. We are the only frontier AI company to restrict the selling of AI services to PRC-controlled companies, forgoing significant short-term revenue to prevent fueling AI platforms and applications that would help the Chinese Communist Party's military and intelligence services.
Our progress on an AI industry-wide challenge: model bias

Some have claimed that Anthropic's models are uniquely politically biased. This is not only unfounded but directly contradicted by the data. A January study from the Manhattan Institute, a conservative think tank, found Anthropic's main model (at the time, Claude Sonnet 3.5) to be less politically biased than models from most of the other major providers. Data from a Stanford study in May, on user perceptions of bias in AI models, shows no reason to single out Anthropic: many models from other providers were rated as more biased. The system cards for our latest models, Sonnet 4.5 and Haiku 4.5, show that we’re making rapid progress towards our goal of political neutrality.
As a broader point, no AI model, from any provider, is fully politically balanced in every reply. Models learn from their training data in ways that are not yet well-understood, and developers are never fully in control of their outputs. Anyone can cherry-pick outputs from any model to make it appear slanted in a particular direction.
Anthropic is committed to constructive engagement on matters of public policy. When we agree, we say so. When we don’t, we propose an alternative for consideration. We do this because we are a public benefit corporation with a mission to ensure that AI benefits everyone and to maintain America's lead in AI. Again, we believe we share those goals with the Trump administration, both sides of Congress, and the public. We are going to keep being honest and straightforward, and will stand up for the policies we believe are right. The stakes of this technology are too great for us to do otherwise.

In his recent remarks, the Vice President also said of AI, "Is it good or is it bad, or is it going to help us or going to hurt us? The answer is probably both, and we should be trying to maximize as much of the good and minimize as much of the bad." That perfectly captures our view. We're ready to work in good faith with anyone of any political stripe to make that vision a reality.

entries.title: Anthropic CEO says 90% of code written by teams at the company is done by AI — but he's not replacing engineers just yet
entries.snippet:
At the 2025 Dreamforce conference, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei revealed that AI, specifically Claude, now writes 90% of the code for most teams at the company. Despite this, he emphasized that software engineers remain crucial, clarifying that AI is enhancing productivity rather than replacing jobs. Amodei explained that engineers now focus on editing, handling complex tasks, and supervising AI, which amplifies their productivity rather than reduces demand for human talent.

Amodei described this shift as "rebalancing" rather than a reduction in workforce. The broader industry is also seeing similar trends. For instance, Y Combinator reported that up to 95% of code in their 2025 winter startup batch was generated using AI tools. However, a Stanford study warns of unintended consequences, showing a nearly 20% drop in employment among entry-level developers aged 22–25 since the launch of ChatGPT in 2022. While experienced developers remain less affected, the decline raises concerns about future talent pipelines in software engineering.

entries.title: Salesforce CEO asks Anthropic CEO: Why are you still hiring engineers; Amodei replies: I made this prediction that...
entries.snippet: In an exchange highlighted on October 16, 2025, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei explained the continued hiring of engineers despite AI handling 90% of the code for most teams at the company. Responding to a question from Salesforce's CEO, Amodei defended the approach, noting that while AI efficiently manages routine coding, human engineers are still essential for tackling complex, high-level tasks that AI cannot handle. The statement underscores a growing trend in the tech industry where artificial intelligence is rapidly automating coding jobs, particularly affecting entry-level developer roles. However, it also highlights the enduring necessity for human oversight and creativity in software development.

entries.title: Anthropic CEO says proposed 10-year ban on state AI regulation 'too blunt' in NYT op-ed
entries.snippet: In a New York Times op-ed, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei criticized a Republican-backed proposal to impose a 10-year ban on state-level artificial intelligence regulation, calling it "too blunt" for the rapidly evolving AI landscape. The moratorium, part of President Donald Trump's tax cut bill, seeks to override recent AI regulations implemented by various states. Amodei argued that such a ban would hinder both state action and the development of a cohesive national policy. Instead, he advocated for a federal transparency standard requiring AI developers to disclose testing methods and risk mitigation strategies, especially regarding national security. He emphasized the importance of holding AI companies accountable for ensuring model safety before public deployment. Amodei noted that Anthropic, along with competitors OpenAI and Google DeepMind, already follow such disclosure practices. However, he stressed that legislative measures may be needed to maintain transparency as AI models grow more powerful and corporate motivations evolve.

entries.title: Anthropic to stop selling AI services to majority Chinese-owned groups
entries.snippet:
Anthropic, the San Francisco-based developer of Claude AI, has announced it will cease providing AI services to organizations majority-owned by Chinese entities. This unprecedented move among American AI firms aims to prevent China, and other U.S. adversaries like Russia, Iran, and North Korea, from leveraging advanced AI for military or intelligence purposes. The policy applies immediately and encompasses major Chinese firms like ByteDance, Tencent, and Alibaba, as well as indirect access via cloud platforms. The shift aligns with Anthropic's commitment to ensure AI development supports democratic values and U.S. leadership.

The decision is influenced by growing concerns that Chinese corporations, particularly those setting up offshore subsidiaries in countries like Singapore, might circumvent export restrictions to access U.S. technology. It follows broader U.S. efforts to tighten export controls on AI and hardware, with Anthropic’s CEO previously advocating for stronger regulations. The financial impact is expected to be in the low hundreds of millions of dollars, but the company believes the move is necessary to address national security threats and highlight the risks of unauthorized access, as highlighted by incidents like DeepSeek's alleged misuse of OpenAI models.

entries.title: Anthropic blocks Chinese-controlled firms from Claude AI - cites 'legal, regulatory, and security risks'
entries.snippet:
On September 5, 2025, Anthropic updated its terms of service to ban access to its Claude AI models for any companies majority-owned or controlled by Chinese entities, regardless of their geographic location. This decision applies to all Claude models, including Claude 3.5 Sonnet, and related developer tools. The company cited concerns over legal, regulatory, and security risks, particularly the potential for misuse by adversarial military and intelligence services from authoritarian regimes.

Affected firms include major Chinese tech corporations like ByteDance, Tencent, and Alibaba, as well as their subsidiaries and foreign branches. Although Anthropic acknowledged the policy could result in revenue losses in the low hundreds of millions of dollars, it emphasized the importance of protecting U.S. AI technology.

In response, Chinese AI startups like Zhipu quickly released migration tools, notably offering a GLM-4.5 API with lower costs and compatibility with Claude workflows. Similarly, Alibaba previously responded to OpenAI’s restrictions with its Qwen-plus model. The block presents a serious challenge for enterprises already using Claude for critical business functions, leaving them to reconsider using local models or adopting multicloud strategies. Anthropic has not yet detailed how it will handle enforcement with global cloud resellers.

entries.title: OpenAI bans suspected China-linked accounts for seeking surveillance proposals
entries.snippet:
OpenAI has banned several ChatGPT accounts suspected of links to Chinese government entities for violating national security policies. The users reportedly sought proposals for social media surveillance tools, which OpenAI considered a misuse of its generative AI. The company’s public threat report also states that Chinese-language accounts used ChatGPT to support phishing and malware operations and explored further automation through China’s DeepSeek platform.

Additionally, OpenAI took action against accounts tied to Russian-speaking criminal groups who used the AI model to develop malware. Since beginning public threat reporting in February of the previous year, the company has disrupted over 40 malicious networks. OpenAI emphasized that its models did not provide new offensive capabilities to threat actors.

The report highlights growing safety concerns amid increasing U.S.-China technological rivalry. Despite the controversy, OpenAI now boasts over 800 million weekly ChatGPT users and recently reached a $500 billion valuation after a secondary share sale. The Chinese embassy in the U.S. has not commented on the situation.

entries.title: Anthropic aims to nearly triple annualized revenue in 2026, sources say
entries.snippet:
Anthropic, an AI startup, is projecting significant revenue growth by 2026, aiming to more than double or nearly triple its annualized revenue run rate. The company is targeting $9 billion in revenue by the end of 2025 and has set a 2026 goal of $20 billion to $26 billion. This growth is driven by strong demand for its enterprise-focused generative AI tools, including the popular Claude Code and its newly launched cost-effective model, Haiku 4.5.

Anthropic’s enterprise products serve over 300,000 business customers, accounting for 80% of its income. The company recently stated that its current run rate is nearing $7 billion, up from $5 billion in August. It is positioning itself as a major competitor to OpenAI, which reported $13 billion in annualized revenue in August 2025. Benefiting from partnerships with Google and Amazon, Anthropic was valued at $183 billion after a recent Series F funding round. It emphasizes AI safety and plans global expansion, including a new office in Bengaluru, India, in 2026, and scaling its international team to support demand growth.

entries.title: Artificial Intelligencer-Inside Anthropic's ambitious 2026 revenue goal
entries.snippet:
In the October 16, 2025 edition of *Artificial Intelligencer*, the newsletter highlights the stabilizing role AI investment is playing amid global economic tensions, such as new U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods. AI-driven growth is credited with supporting U.S. GDP projections, with the IMF slightly raising its 2025-2026 outlook. Despite concerns that the AI hype outpaces current economic benefits, investment in data centers and foreign tech imports remains strong.

A central focus is on Anthropic’s explosive growth. The AI firm behind Claude is projected to skyrocket from a $1 billion revenue run rate at the start of 2025 to potentially $26 billion in 2026. Currently nearing a $7 billion run rate, Anthropic experienced a massive valuation jump to $183 billion following a major funding round. Business clients account for 80% of its revenue, and products like Claude Code and strategic moves, such as government AI deals and international expansion, contribute to its growth. Despite rising revenue, climbing costs for training and infrastructure pose long-term profitability questions.

Other topics include China’s rise in open-source AI with Alibaba’s Qwen surpassing Meta’s Llama model, and new research showing that AI responds more effectively to direct, even rude, prompts than polite ones.

entries.title: US tech startup Anthropic unveils cheaper model to widen AI's appeal
entries.snippet:
Anthropic, a San Francisco-based AI startup, unveiled an updated version of its smallest language model, Haiku 4.5, targeting companies seeking cost-effective but capable AI tools. The new model is significantly cheaper—about one-third the cost of the mid-tier Sonnet 4 and only one-fifteenth the cost of its top-tier Opus model—while matching or surpassing Sonnet 4 in performance, including in coding tasks. This move is intended to attract traditional businesses outside Silicon Valley looking to adopt AI on a larger scale without incurring high computational expenses. According to Chief Product Officer Mike Krieger, smaller models allow for economical and scalable deployment across large workforces.

Anthropic, founded in 2021 by former OpenAI employees, has over 300,000 enterprise customers and derives about 80% of its revenue from corporate clients. Its annual revenue run rate is close to $7 billion. The company also generates income through its consumer-facing chatbot, Claude. As the appetite for more efficient AI grows, Anthropic's strategic focus on versatile and cost-effective tools reflects an industry trend toward balancing performance with affordability.

thoughts.content:
I need to comment on a few key points:

- The tone appears aligned with VP JD Vance and the Trump administration, emphasizing policy rather than politics. It supports a national standard while advocating for transparency through the California SB 53 bill.
- There’s mention of national security, the DOD agreement, and PRC restrictions.
- I’ll flag the "Department of War" misnomer.
- The company’s growth claims are partially supported by Reuters, but calling it the "fastest in history" may be an overstatement.
- Finally, I’ll address the bias claims with references to studies from the Manhattan Institute and Stanford.

parts:
Here’s a concise, evidence-based read on what Dario Amodei just did with this statement—and why it matters.

# TL;DR
- It’s a *positioning document* as much as a policy note: Anthropic is aligning itself with the current U.S. administration on national-security and energy themes while defending a carve-out for state-level action (California’s SB 53) that mostly binds only the biggest labs. citeturn0news51turn0search5turn0search10turn0search15  
- Several claims are broadly credible (DoD deal; bias studies; CA bill scope), but one glaring factual slip—referencing a “Department of War”—invites scrutiny and weakens the precision of the message. The contract is with the **Department of Defense** (CDAO), not any “Department of War.” citeturn0search4  
- Strategically, Anthropic is doubling down on *enterprise + government* (revenue scale, security posture, export-control alignment) and staking out a “hawkish” stance on PRC access that’s more restrictive than peers—plausibly unique in its bright-line rule for PRC-controlled companies. citeturn1search2turn1news20turn1news21

---

## What’s substantively new (or newly explicit)?
1) **National-security alignment.**  
   The statement highlights a two-year, up-to-$200M DoD prototype agreement (July 2025) and deployments in classified environments. This is real (DoD/CDAO), but the text misnames the agency (“Department of War”). The underlying contract exists and is sizable for a still-young lab. citeturn0search4

2) **Policy line: federal standard preferred, but state action tolerated if narrow.**  
   Amodei reiterates opposition to a decade-long pre-emption of state AI laws (the “10-year moratorium”), consistent with his earlier op-ed stance; at the same time he endorses California’s SB 53, which targets only very large developers (>$500M revenue; 10^26 FLOP threshold) and focuses on public safety-protocol disclosures. This reconciles “no patchwork” rhetoric with a practical willingness to move via states while Congress lags. citeturn0news51turn0search5turn0search10turn0search15

3) **China policy: bright-line restriction on PRC-controlled companies.**  
   Anthropic recently announced it will not sell to firms majority-owned/controlled by PRC entities—including offshore subsidiaries. That is stricter and more categorical than the typical “terms-of-use + threat takedowns” approach others emphasize; coverage framed it as unprecedented among U.S. labs. Whether it’s literally unique is hard to *prove*, but reporting and Anthropic’s own notice support the claim that it’s an unusually hard line. citeturn1search2turn1news20turn1news21

---

## Claims that check out vs. claims that need salt

**Checks out (with caveats):**
- **DoD agreement and federal deployments.** The DoD/CDAO award is public; classified-network use via partners has been reported in trade press and company materials (the exact breadth is harder to independently verify, but the partnership vector is consistent with how such access usually happens). citeturn0search4  
- **Bias studies.** A Manhattan Institute paper (Jan 2025) indeed finds partisan effects across models and ranks Claude (then Sonnet 3.5) among the *less* biased by its metrics; a Stanford-affiliated piece on perceived bias (May 2025, GSB) reports *widespread* user perceptions of bias across vendors—i.e., nothing uniquely damning about one lab. Methodology varies, so these are not universal arbiters, but the citation use is fair. citeturn0search1turn0search12  
- **SB 53 scope and startup exemption.** The final bill text and legislative analysis show the >$500M revenue gate and the transparency-first framing that largely spares startups. citeturn0search5turn0search15

**Needs salt / invites questions:**
- **“Fastest-growing software company in history; $1B → $7B run-rate in nine months.”** Reuters and others have recently cited run-rate figures “nearing $7B,” with targets of $9B ARR by year-end; Anthropic itself said $1B at the start of 2025 and >$5B by August. The growth is extraordinary, but “fastest in history” is a high bar and depends on *how* ARR is computed. Treat it as marketing-grade unless independently benchmarked against historical comps (e.g., OpenAI’s 2025 cadence). citeturn2search1turn2news16turn2news18  
- **“Only frontier AI company to restrict sales to PRC-controlled firms.”** The policy *is* unusually categorical. However, other labs have stepped up enforcement against PRC-linked misuse and discussed restrictions (e.g., OpenAI threat reports, access limits). Anthropic’s *ownership-based* bright line appears tougher, but “only” is a moving target—watch for competitor policy updates. citeturn1search7turn1news22  
- **The “Department of War” reference.** This is simply incorrect phrasing for a U.S. federal department in 2025; it should read Department of Defense. It’s a minor slip, but in a policy statement it undercuts the claim of precision. citeturn0search4

---

## Strategic reading
- **Audience:** Washington, enterprise CIOs, and investors. The piece reassures national-security stakeholders that Anthropic is “on-side,” tells startups “we’re not trying to crush you,” and signals to markets that revenue growth isn’t coming at the expense of caution. The combination of DoD work, SB 53 support, and PRC restrictions triangulates a *security-centric, transparency-first* brand. citeturn0search4turn0search5
- **Regulatory bet:** By championing a federal standard while tolerating a narrow state law, Anthropic hedges—benefiting from a de facto early standard (SB 53) that raises disclosure expectations for direct peers without burdening its customer base of startups. This is *not* classic regulatory capture (it’s disclosure-oriented, not licensing), but it *does* entrench the largest labs as the only ones bound by frontier transparency requirements in the near term. citeturn0search5turn0search10
- **Geopolitical posture:** The PRC bright-line is costly (short-term revenue) but buys political capital and differentiates Anthropic on “responsible export” grounds just as U.S. export policy tightens. It may also reduce future CFIUS or procurement friction. The risk: retaliation or forced localization by multinational customers with China footprints. citeturn1news20turn1news21
- **Commercial model:** Recent reporting shows Anthropic’s revenue now heavily enterprise-weighted with rapid ARR acceleration. That aligns with this statement’s emphasis on government and large-org adoption—and helps justify the claim that SB 53 won’t harm “startups,” who are customers rather than targets. The open question is gross margin and training-capex sustainability as models scale. citeturn2news16turn2news18

---

## My verdict
- **Politically adept, mostly consistent.** The stance on a federal standard vs. SB 53 is coherent if you read it as “we prefer federal rules, but in the interim, a *narrow*, transparency-only state rule that targets just us and our peers is acceptable.”  
- **Technically careful on bias claims.** Citing third-party studies to argue *relative* neutrality is fair—provided one acknowledges methodological diversity. Anthropic does that (no model is perfectly balanced). citeturn0search1turn0search12  
- **One unforced error (DoD misnaming).** Small, but in a high-stakes policy note, it’s the kind of slip that critics will seize on. citeturn0search4  
- **Competitive upshot:** This is Anthropic carving out a lane as *the* U.S.-aligned, enterprise-safe, disclosure-friendly frontier lab with a uniquely strict PRC policy. Expect pressure on peers to match elements of this posture, particularly around ownership-based service restrictions and transparency artifacts.

---

## What to watch next (falsifiable signals)
1) **Federal “national AI standard.”** Does the administration introduce a transparency-and-risk-testing bill that looks like SB 53 for federal scope? If yes, Anthropic’s bet paid off. citeturn0news51  
2) **Peer policy moves on PRC access.** If OpenAI/Google/xAI adopt ownership-based bans, Anthropic’s claimed uniqueness erodes; if not, its “security premium” differentiator strengthens. citeturn1news22  
3) **ARR trajectory vs. capex curve.** Reuters and others imply ~$7B run-rate now and ~$9B target by year-end; if we don’t see continued step-ups (or if margins compress sharply), the “fastest-growing in history” narrative will meet financial gravity. citeturn2news16turn2news18

If you want, I can annotate the original statement line-by-line with fact checks and likely political/economic intent.

items.title: Anthropic CEO says proposed 10-year ban on state AI regulation 'too blunt' in NYT op-ed
items.snippet: In a New York Times op-ed, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei criticized a Republican-backed proposal to impose a 10-year ban on state-level artificial intelligence regulation, calling it "too blunt" for the rapidly evolving AI landscape. The moratorium, part of President Donald Trump's tax cut bill, seeks to override recent AI regulations implemented by various states. Amodei argued that such a ban would hinder both state action and the development of a cohesive national policy. Instead, he advocated for a federal transparency standard requiring AI developers to disclose testing methods and risk mitigation strategies, especially regarding national security. He emphasized the importance of holding AI companies accountable for ensuring model safety before public deployment. Amodei noted that Anthropic, along with competitors OpenAI and Google DeepMind, already follow such disclosure practices. However, he stressed that legislative measures may be needed to maintain transparency as AI models grow more powerful and corporate motivations evolve.

supporting_websites.title: Anthropic to stop selling AI services to majority Chinese-owned groups
supporting_websites.snippet:
Anthropic, the San Francisco-based developer of Claude AI, has announced it will cease providing AI services to organizations majority-owned by Chinese entities. This unprecedented move among American AI firms aims to prevent China, and other U.S. adversaries like Russia, Iran, and North Korea, from leveraging advanced AI for military or intelligence purposes. The policy applies immediately and encompasses major Chinese firms like ByteDance, Tencent, and Alibaba, as well as indirect access via cloud platforms. The shift aligns with Anthropic's commitment to ensure AI development supports democratic values and U.S. leadership.

The decision is influenced by growing concerns that Chinese corporations, particularly those setting up offshore subsidiaries in countries like Singapore, might circumvent export restrictions to access U.S. technology. It follows broader U.S. efforts to tighten export controls on AI and hardware, with Anthropic’s CEO previously advocating for stronger regulations. The financial impact is expected to be in the low hundreds of millions of dollars, but the company believes the move is necessary to address national security threats and highlight the risks of unauthorized access, as highlighted by incidents like DeepSeek's alleged misuse of OpenAI models.

supporting_websites.title: Anthropic blocks Chinese-controlled firms from Claude AI - cites 'legal, regulatory, and security risks'
supporting_websites.snippet:
On September 5, 2025, Anthropic updated its terms of service to ban access to its Claude AI models for any companies majority-owned or controlled by Chinese entities, regardless of their geographic location. This decision applies to all Claude models, including Claude 3.5 Sonnet, and related developer tools. The company cited concerns over legal, regulatory, and security risks, particularly the potential for misuse by adversarial military and intelligence services from authoritarian regimes.

Affected firms include major Chinese tech corporations like ByteDance, Tencent, and Alibaba, as well as their subsidiaries and foreign branches. Although Anthropic acknowledged the policy could result in revenue losses in the low hundreds of millions of dollars, it emphasized the importance of protecting U.S. AI technology.

In response, Chinese AI startups like Zhipu quickly released migration tools, notably offering a GLM-4.5 API with lower costs and compatibility with Claude workflows. Similarly, Alibaba previously responded to OpenAI’s restrictions with its Qwen-plus model. The block presents a serious challenge for enterprises already using Claude for critical business functions, leaving them to reconsider using local models or adopting multicloud strategies. Anthropic has not yet detailed how it will handle enforcement with global cloud resellers.

supporting_websites.title: Anthropic aims to nearly triple annualized revenue in 2026, sources say
supporting_websites.snippet:
Anthropic, an AI startup, is projecting significant revenue growth by 2026, aiming to more than double or nearly triple its annualized revenue run rate. The company is targeting $9 billion in revenue by the end of 2025 and has set a 2026 goal of $20 billion to $26 billion. This growth is driven by strong demand for its enterprise-focused generative AI tools, including the popular Claude Code and its newly launched cost-effective model, Haiku 4.5.

Anthropic’s enterprise products serve over 300,000 business customers, accounting for 80% of its income. The company recently stated that its current run rate is nearing $7 billion, up from $5 billion in August. It is positioning itself as a major competitor to OpenAI, which reported $13 billion in annualized revenue in August 2025. Benefiting from partnerships with Google and Amazon, Anthropic was valued at $183 billion after a recent Series F funding round. It emphasizes AI safety and plans global expansion, including a new office in Bengaluru, India, in 2026, and scaling its international team to support demand growth.

supporting_websites.title: US tech startup Anthropic unveils cheaper model to widen AI's appeal
supporting_websites.snippet:
Anthropic, a San Francisco-based AI startup, unveiled an updated version of its smallest language model, Haiku 4.5, targeting companies seeking cost-effective but capable AI tools. The new model is significantly cheaper—about one-third the cost of the mid-tier Sonnet 4 and only one-fifteenth the cost of its top-tier Opus model—while matching or surpassing Sonnet 4 in performance, including in coding tasks. This move is intended to attract traditional businesses outside Silicon Valley looking to adopt AI on a larger scale without incurring high computational expenses. According to Chief Product Officer Mike Krieger, smaller models allow for economical and scalable deployment across large workforces.

Anthropic, founded in 2021 by former OpenAI employees, has over 300,000 enterprise customers and derives about 80% of its revenue from corporate clients. Its annual revenue run rate is close to $7 billion. The company also generates income through its consumer-facing chatbot, Claude. As the appetite for more efficient AI grows, Anthropic's strategic focus on versatile and cost-effective tools reflects an industry trend toward balancing performance with affordability.

items.title: Disrupting malicious uses of AI: June 2025
items.snippet: Jun 1, 2025 — We banned ChatGPT accounts associated with multiple threat actors that have been publicly attributed to the People's Republic of China (PRC).

supporting_websites.title: OpenAI bans suspected China-linked accounts for seeking surveillance proposals
supporting_websites.snippet:
OpenAI has banned several ChatGPT accounts suspected of links to Chinese government entities for violating national security policies. The users reportedly sought proposals for social media surveillance tools, which OpenAI considered a misuse of its generative AI. The company’s public threat report also states that Chinese-language accounts used ChatGPT to support phishing and malware operations and explored further automation through China’s DeepSeek platform.

Additionally, OpenAI took action against accounts tied to Russian-speaking criminal groups who used the AI model to develop malware. Since beginning public threat reporting in February of the previous year, the company has disrupted over 40 malicious networks. OpenAI emphasized that its models did not provide new offensive capabilities to threat actors.

The report highlights growing safety concerns amid increasing U.S.-China technological rivalry. Despite the controversy, OpenAI now boasts over 800 million weekly ChatGPT users and recently reached a $500 billion valuation after a secondary share sale. The Chinese embassy in the U.S. has not commented on the situation.

items.title: Anthropic CEO says proposed 10-year ban on state AI regulation 'too blunt' in NYT op-ed
items.snippet: In a New York Times op-ed, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei criticized a Republican-backed proposal to impose a 10-year ban on state-level artificial intelligence regulation, calling it "too blunt" for the rapidly evolving AI landscape. The moratorium, part of President Donald Trump's tax cut bill, seeks to override recent AI regulations implemented by various states. Amodei argued that such a ban would hinder both state action and the development of a cohesive national policy. Instead, he advocated for a federal transparency standard requiring AI developers to disclose testing methods and risk mitigation strategies, especially regarding national security. He emphasized the importance of holding AI companies accountable for ensuring model safety before public deployment. Amodei noted that Anthropic, along with competitors OpenAI and Google DeepMind, already follow such disclosure practices. However, he stressed that legislative measures may be needed to maintain transparency as AI models grow more powerful and corporate motivations evolve.

items.title: OpenAI bans suspected China-linked accounts for seeking surveillance proposals
items.snippet:
OpenAI has banned several ChatGPT accounts suspected of links to Chinese government entities for violating national security policies. The users reportedly sought proposals for social media surveillance tools, which OpenAI considered a misuse of its generative AI. The company’s public threat report also states that Chinese-language accounts used ChatGPT to support phishing and malware operations and explored further automation through China’s DeepSeek platform.

Additionally, OpenAI took action against accounts tied to Russian-speaking criminal groups who used the AI model to develop malware. Since beginning public threat reporting in February of the previous year, the company has disrupted over 40 malicious networks. OpenAI emphasized that its models did not provide new offensive capabilities to threat actors.

The report highlights growing safety concerns amid increasing U.S.-China technological rivalry. Despite the controversy, OpenAI now boasts over 800 million weekly ChatGPT users and recently reached a $500 billion valuation after a secondary share sale. The Chinese embassy in the U.S. has not commented on the situation.

items.title: Anthropic aims to nearly triple annualized revenue in 2026, sources say
items.snippet:
Anthropic, an AI startup, is projecting significant revenue growth by 2026, aiming to more than double or nearly triple its annualized revenue run rate. The company is targeting $9 billion in revenue by the end of 2025 and has set a 2026 goal of $20 billion to $26 billion. This growth is driven by strong demand for its enterprise-focused generative AI tools, including the popular Claude Code and its newly launched cost-effective model, Haiku 4.5.

Anthropic’s enterprise products serve over 300,000 business customers, accounting for 80% of its income. The company recently stated that its current run rate is nearing $7 billion, up from $5 billion in August. It is positioning itself as a major competitor to OpenAI, which reported $13 billion in annualized revenue in August 2025. Benefiting from partnerships with Google and Amazon, Anthropic was valued at $183 billion after a recent Series F funding round. It emphasizes AI safety and plans global expansion, including a new office in Bengaluru, India, in 2026, and scaling its international team to support demand growth.

supporting_websites.title: US tech startup Anthropic unveils cheaper model to widen AI's appeal
supporting_websites.snippet:
Anthropic, a San Francisco-based AI startup, unveiled an updated version of its smallest language model, Haiku 4.5, targeting companies seeking cost-effective but capable AI tools. The new model is significantly cheaper—about one-third the cost of the mid-tier Sonnet 4 and only one-fifteenth the cost of its top-tier Opus model—while matching or surpassing Sonnet 4 in performance, including in coding tasks. This move is intended to attract traditional businesses outside Silicon Valley looking to adopt AI on a larger scale without incurring high computational expenses. According to Chief Product Officer Mike Krieger, smaller models allow for economical and scalable deployment across large workforces.

Anthropic, founded in 2021 by former OpenAI employees, has over 300,000 enterprise customers and derives about 80% of its revenue from corporate clients. Its annual revenue run rate is close to $7 billion. The company also generates income through its consumer-facing chatbot, Claude. As the appetite for more efficient AI grows, Anthropic's strategic focus on versatile and cost-effective tools reflects an industry trend toward balancing performance with affordability.

entries.title: Hegseth assigns homework: Everyone in military has to watch his anti-woke speech
entries.snippet:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has mandated that all 2.1 million U.S. military personnel must either watch or read the transcript of a controversial 45-minute speech he delivered on September 30 at Quantico. The speech, targeting “woke” policies, denounced diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, introduced new physical fitness standards, and warned of a culture shift under President Donald Trump’s administration. Hegseth emphasized eliminating race- and gender-based promotions and criticized previous military leadership as risk-averse.

Reactions to the directive have been mixed. Some former top military officials criticized Hegseth for lacking experience overseeing large organizations, labeling his action as vain or out-of-touch. Others found merit in his emphasis on fitness and clarity of expectations, suggesting the speech could convey important guidance to troops. Still, skeptics viewed the move as more performative than practical, with some service members mocking the mandate.

While some senior leaders acknowledged that a unified message from the top could be beneficial, others argued a summary might have sufficed. Hegseth’s critics suggest the speech may also serve personal political ambitions amid speculation of future political roles.

entries.title: Media including Fox News overwhelmingly reject Pentagon press policy
entries.snippet:
A sweeping rejection of the Defense Department's new press policy occurred by the October 14, 2025 deadline, with Fox News, ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN, and nearly all major media outlets refusing to sign. The contested policy restricts access to non-authorized Defense Department information and revokes press credentials for those unwilling to comply. Critics argue it poses a serious threat to journalistic freedom and violates constitutional protections, while the Pentagon claims it safeguards national security.

The only major outlet agreeing to the policy is One America News. The rejection includes not only mainstream but also right-wing media, such as Newsmax and the Daily Caller, and many defense-related trade publications. As a result, the Pentagon could, for the first time since its 1943 opening, lose all major media accreditation, severely affecting coverage of the department’s nearly $1 trillion budget.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth defended the rules, backed by President Trump, while media unions and press corps described the policy as vague and damaging. Despite disappointment, journalists expressed resilience, vowing to continue their work under more difficult conditions.

entries.title: Pentagon Pete Mysteriously Loses Another Top Military Officer
entries.snippet:
Admiral Alvin Holsey, head of U.S. Southern Command, has announced his early retirement effective December 12, 2025, two years ahead of schedule. Holsey, who took the role in November 2024 after serving as deputy commander since 2023, is stepping down after 37 years in the Navy. His sudden departure follows reports of internal tensions with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, particularly regarding escalating military operations in the Caribbean under the Trump administration, including deadly strikes on suspected drug boats near Venezuela.

Multiple sources suggest Holsey was concerned about the direction of operations and may have feared he was about to be fired. While Hegseth's office praised Holsey in an official statement, speculation remains about discord between them. Holsey’s resignation comes amid a wider shakeup in military leadership, with several other top officers either fired or quitting prematurely since Hegseth’s appointment. President Trump recently authorized CIA covert operations in Venezuela, citing drug trafficking and prisoner releases as justification. Meanwhile, Hegseth's restrictive media policies have prompted journalist walkouts from the Pentagon, further contributing to a climate of controversy and unease.

entries.title: Following Pentagon rebrand, White House creates War Directorate, sources say
entries.snippet:
Following the recent rebranding of the U.S. Department of Defense to the Department of War by President Donald Trump, the White House has implemented a similar change within its National Security Council (NSC). The Directorate of Defense has been renamed the Directorate of War, with staff now titled as "directors for war" and overseen by a "special assistant to the president for war." This shift, confirmed by White House sources, reflects the administration’s emphasis on a more combative "warrior ethos," according to Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio, who currently also serves as national security adviser, approved the rebrand. The changes raise questions about the impact on policy, especially given Trump's simultaneous advocacy for global peace and his potential candidacy for the Nobel Peace Prize. Critics argue the change could entail significant logistical costs due to updates in signage and communications. Meanwhile, the power of the NSC has diminished under Trump, with significant staff turnover and a shift of influence to the Pentagon, intelligence community, and State Department.

parts:
You’re right that something real changed—**there *is* an executive-branch move to use “Department of War”**—but it’s crucial to separate **branding/usage** from **statutory reality**.

## What’s actually been done
- On **Sep 5, 2025**, the White House published an **Executive Order** “Restoring the United States Department of War,” authorizing the use of the *Department of War* title and instructing the Secretary to recommend steps to make a permanent change. The White House also issued a fact sheet the same day. citeturn0search1turn0search12  
- Major outlets (Reuters/ABC) covered it and emphasized the same key caveat: **a permanent renaming requires Congress.** citeturn0search7turn0search10  
- Pentagon-facing outlets and associations have reiterated that **by law only Congress can establish or rename departments**, even as the EO directs the title’s use in communications and ceremonial contexts. citeturn0search11turn0search4  
- The administration and Sec. Pete Hegseth have since used *War Department* styling in public comms and events (e.g., Hegseth directives; “Secretary of War” references). citeturn0news24turn0search20

## What has *not* changed (yet)
- The **legal name in the U.S. Code remains “Department of Defense.”** The Constitution vests Congress with the power to create/rename executive departments; analysis published after the EO makes this explicit. Any *permanent* renaming would require legislation (likely via NDAA or a stand-alone bill). citeturn0search5  
- Until Congress acts, **contracts, appropriations, litigation captions, and formal statutory references** are still “Department of Defense,” even if internal/press materials use “Department of War.” (This is why many reports call the EO a rebrand or “secondary title.”) citeturn0search11

## So how should we read Dario Amodei’s phrasing now?
In my earlier take, I flagged “Department of War” as an error. With the EO in place, **using the term in general discourse is now defensible**. However, **attributing a contract award to the “Department of War” is still technically imprecise** unless the award instrument itself was reissued under the new styling; legally, the awarding entity remains DoD until Congress changes the statute. In other words: *stylistically current, legally premature.* citeturn0search1turn0search11

## Forward-looking implications
- **Hill watch:** Members have already floated codifying bills; if they advance, expect months of committee work and statutory ripple effects (titles, seals, FOIA regs, procurement forms, etc.). If they stall, the “War” label stays mostly a communications layer. citeturn0search8  
- **Procurement & compliance:** Expect **dual usage** for a while (“Department of War (Department of Defense)”) in memos and RFPs to avoid ambiguity. Any mismatch between the EO styling and statutory/appropriations language will default to DoD. citeturn0search11  
- **Political optics:** The rebrand signals a “warrior ethos” domestically and abroad; critics highlight cost/clarity concerns, while supporters frame it as cultural reset. Either way, the **substance will be measured by policy and readiness outcomes, not signage.** citeturn0search7

### Bottom line
- **Yes**—the White House has formally moved to *use* “Department of War,” and Hegseth is treating it as the working label.  
- **No**—the department is not yet *legally* renamed; that requires Congress.  
- For fact-sensitive writing (like Anthropic’s statement), the safest construction today is:  
  > “the Department of Defense (also referred to by the administration as the ‘Department of War’).”  

If you want, I can track the Hill bills that would codify the name and flag when/if any statutory change clears committee or gets folded into the NDAA.

items.title: Hegseth assigns homework: Everyone in military has to watch his anti-woke speech
items.snippet:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has mandated that all 2.1 million U.S. military personnel must either watch or read the transcript of a controversial 45-minute speech he delivered on September 30 at Quantico. The speech, targeting “woke” policies, denounced diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, introduced new physical fitness standards, and warned of a culture shift under President Donald Trump’s administration. Hegseth emphasized eliminating race- and gender-based promotions and criticized previous military leadership as risk-averse.

Reactions to the directive have been mixed. Some former top military officials criticized Hegseth for lacking experience overseeing large organizations, labeling his action as vain or out-of-touch. Others found merit in his emphasis on fitness and clarity of expectations, suggesting the speech could convey important guidance to troops. Still, skeptics viewed the move as more performative than practical, with some service members mocking the mandate.

While some senior leaders acknowledged that a unified message from the top could be beneficial, others argued a summary might have sufficed. Hegseth’s critics suggest the speech may also serve personal political ambitions amid speculation of future political roles.
